Nuestra socia tiene  una tienda de abarrotes hace 6 años, trabaja de domingo a domingo desde las cinco y media de la mañana hasta las diez de la noche. También de  jueves a  domingos vende un delicioso sancocho (sopa típica de yuca y choclo).
 
Doña María tiene 45 años, es soltera y tiene un hijo de 16 años de edad que estudia en un colegio de la ciudad. Tiene casa propia la misma que es herencia de sus padres.

Es socia de la banca comunal hace 6 años y los créditos le han ayudado en el crecimiento de su tienda, su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de productos como arroz, fideos, azúcar, aceite, etc.
 
Su sueño es  que su hijo sea un profesional.
texts.en:
Mrs. María C. is a member of the Las Flores communal bank and lives in Ricuarte parish located in the northeast of Cuenca canton.  The population is mostly dedicated to farming and raising animals although they also work in various jobs in the city of Cuenca.  Its church and the local gastronomy are tourist attractions.

She has had a grocery store for the last 6 years.  She is open from Sunday to Sunday from 5:30am until 10pm.  Also, from Thursdays through Sundays she sells a delicious “sancocho” (typical regional manioc and tuber stew)

María is 45 years old, single and has a 16 year old son who goes to secondary school in the city.  She has her own house which she inherited from her parents.

She has been a member of the communal bank for 6 years and the loans have helped her store grow.  The new loan will be used to buy products like: rice, noodles, sugar, cooking oil, etc.

Her dream is that her son becomes a professional.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Filena De La Cruz

texts.es:
Filena es una pequeña comerciante, que ha crecido en su comercio, gracias al esfuerzo y los financiamientos que la institución ha dado. Vende cosméticos, ropa nueva y accesorios como: cartera, bolsos, zapatos entre otros encargos que le hacen.
Iniciando hace varios años, con pocos productos, con ahorros de su esposo, el cual trabaja como cadete de taxi. 
Hoy en día las ventas están bajas, es por eso quiere invertir más en ropa, y cosméticos logrando mejorar  las ventas, y poder cubrir los gastos básicos de su hogar.
texts.en:
Filena is a small merchant who has grown in her business thanks to effort and loans from the institution.  She sells cosmetics, new clothes and accessories like: wallets, purses and shoes among other orders she gets.  She started out several years ago with just a few products using her husband’s savings; he is a taxi driver.

Currently, sales have slacked off so she wants to invest in more clothes and cosmetics in order to improve sales and cover basic household expenses.

loans.use: Will buy clothes, cosmetics and other products to increase sales.

loans.name: Nancy Lucía

texts.es:
La Señora. Nancy G. es socia del banco comunal Las Flores, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es conocida por la belleza de su centro histórico, su gente, su cultura y tradiciones y es  la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador.
 
Doña Nancy tiene de 45 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 22, 16 y 15 años de edad, su primera hija es casada y vive en su casa compartiendo gastos, la segunda  estudia en un colegio de la ciudad, su tercer hijo es un joven especial tiene parálisis cerebral. Su esposo es carpintero. Con el trabajo y esfuerzo  conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

La Señora Nancy se dedica a la venta de viandas (lunch o comida), actividad que la realiza hace 6 años, labora de lunes a viernes desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 2 de la tarde y lo demás de su tiempo lo dedica a su hijo.
 
Es socia de la banca comunal hace 4 años, beneficiándose de los créditos en su hogar. Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de víveres para la elaboración de sus viandas.
 
Su sueño es que algún día su hijo pueda caminar y desearía realizarle el tratamiento con las células madres pero es muy costoso.
texts.en:
Mrs Nancy G. is a member of the Las Flores community bank.  She lives in the city of Cuenca which is known for the beauty of its historic center, its people, its culture and its traditions.  It is the third most important city in Ecuador.

Nancy is 45 years old.  She is married and has 3 children aged 22, 16 and 15.  Her first daughter is married and lives in her house sharing expenses.  The second daughter studies in a school in the city, her third -  a son – is a special young man who has cerebral palsy.  Her husband is a carpenter.  Through their work and effort, the family have managed to build their own home.

Nancy sells meals (lunches) which she has been doing for 6 years.  She works from Monday to Friday from 8 in the morning until 2 in the afternoon.  The rest of her time she devotes to her son.

She has been a member of the community bank for 4 years, using the loans to benefit her household.  Her new loan will be used to buy supplies to make her meals.

Her dream is that some day her son will be able to walk. She would like to be able to get him stem cell treatment but it is very expensive.

loans.use: To buy supplies

loans.name: Julio Ramon

texts.es:
Julio de 20 años, vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana, llamada las orquídeas porque en su descubrimiento habían muchas flores orquídeas). Tiene un puesto de fotocopia y venta de cuadernos. 

Cuando el era pequeño la mama tenia una papelería poco a poco el fue criado en un mundo de ventas y papeles, hasta que decidió tener su propio negocio comprando una fotocopiado y unos cuantos cuadernos. Poco a poco con esfuerzo obtuvo clientela, en la actualidad trabaja desde las 07h30am hasta las 22h00pm todos los días. Cada cuadernos lo vende a $ 1.20, las copias a $ 0.10 según el color. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una copiadora y papelería para mejorar el servicio de su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener una papelería para asegurar su ahorros.
texts.en:
Julio is 20 years old and lives in Orquídeas de Guayaquil (an urban area named after the many orchids that existed when the place was discovered). He owns a stall where he makes photocopies and sells notebooks. 

When he was young his mother ran a stationery’s shop, and he was brought up little by little in a world of sales and paper, until he decided running his own shop by buying a copy machine and a few notebooks. He earned some customers little by little and with effort: he currently works form 7.30 am to 22 pm every day. He sells every notebook for $ 1.20 and he charges $0.10 a copy or more according to them being black and white or color.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy a copy machine and stationery to improve the service offered in his shop. In the future he wants to run a stationery’s shop to increase his savings.

loans.use: To buy a copy machine and stationery.

loans.name: Collins

texts.en:
Collins L. began working with cars at a very young age with his father who was a mechanic. In fact, he required Collins to help him with car repairs as a means of discipline when his son got into any sort of trouble.

Collins says, “What started as a punishment turned into a profession.” Collins had repaired cars for over 30 years at several different corporations in New Orleans when, a year ago, he decided to pursue his dream of starting his own business, L. Automotives. His wife, Helen, had already started a daycare facility at the same time Collins started his car shop. They used their savings and investments to make their start-ups successful.

With only one employee, Collins is very busy. He juggles between answering the phones, helping walk-in customers, and repairing cars. The recent oil spill in New Orleans has not helped his situation because many of his customers were laid off so they stopped spending their money even on car tune-ups and repairs. One of Collins main services is changing oil and the oil prices have increased.

Collins plans to stock up on car parts with the loan: brake pads, tires, etc. Collins says, “I can’t spend as much money as I used to because it all goes back into the business. Even though being self-employed has its ups and downs, working for yourself is always worth it.”

loans.use: Car Parts: tires, brake pads, etc.

loans.name: Eveling Violeta

texts.es:
Eveling es una señora esforzada, se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y alquila un cuarto. Logrando tener una entrada fija para surtir los gastos.
 Hace varios años comenzó a vender con dinero que su esposo dio. El está trabajando en el país vecino de Costa Rica, en donde con sus remesas que envía y los financiamientos de la institución ha logrado las mejoras  a su vivienda. 
Con el crédito anterior logro terminar el porche, lo cual iba a comenzar la construcción del muro, lo que solo hizo un comienzo, y que desea terminarlo con este préstamo en donde comprara materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro y otros para terminar la obra.
Lo que será de gran beneficio para reguardar la seguridad de su familia, y de su pequeño solar.
texts.en:
Eveling is a hard-working woman who is in the business of selling beauty supplies. She also rents a room in her house, an activity that provides her with a regular income that helps pay for household expenses.

She started her business years ago and now her husband, who gave her the initial capital for it, sends her money from Costa Rica, where he currently works. She has been using the money he sends as well as micro-loans she's applied for to make improvements to their house. She used her first loan to build an entry porch and to get an outside wall started. She plans to use this second loan to finish the wall, which will help keep her family and her home safe. In order to do so, she will need to buy more construction material: stone, sand, cement, iron, etc.

loans.use: to buy construction material to finish building an outside wall to protect her house

loans.name: Damion

texts.en:
Damion J. started his construction company, Rock Enterprises Construction, 11 years ago in New Orleans when he realized that many of his friends and family who hired businesses to do repairs were often charged unreasonable prices. He started his business to provide affordable and quality work to residents of New Orleans and has since moved to the commercial and industrial sectors. Five years ago, Damion had to shut down his business after Hurricane Katrina hit the Louisiana coast. Through perserverence and hard work, Damion was able to pull his business together. There was fewer work with fewer people in New Orleans, and also, less people willing to invest in their homes. For people who needed renovation, many unlicensed contractors came to New Orleans and took advantage of that demand. All these factors contributed to making it very difficult for Damion to build his business back up again.

This same situation has happened again with the recent oil spill. Damion had seven large residential projects planned before the oil spill that would have brought almost $ 1 million to his company. However, because of the oil spill devastating the area, investors were not as willing to invest in these homes and decided to not go through with the projects. Damion and his 15 employees had been counting on those projects and now he does not have enough money to tide the business over until they get their next big project, which is currently under way. With this loan, Damion plans to  pay his employees and rent big machinery. Without this loan, Damion would not be able to complete this big project and would be forced to let go of some of his employees.

loans.use: New machinery and pay employees for next big project

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es:
Rosario León A., es una joven de 38 años que vive con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 10 y 14 años de edad en el municipio de Malambo, a 15 minutos de la ciudad de Barranquilla; allí se dedica a la comercialización de víveres y refrescos,  desde que llegó de apartadó Antioquia donde trabajaba en un restaurante de una finca y vendía los almuerzos de los empleados, fue allí donde sintió el deseo de ser independiente por primera vez y cuando ocurrieron los problemas de orden publico en la zonda donde ella vivía, no lo dudó y con su familia llegó a este municipio y emprendió su propio negocio, desde los 24 años de edad cuando ya estaba casada . Al principio tuvo muchos desafíos de adaptación, pero gradualmente “se han ido emparejando las cargas”. Su primer capital fue resultado de la indemnización que recibió su esposo cuando trabajaba, con ello inició una tienda, pero el crédito mal otorgado, fueron causa de su quiebra y como ella siempre se ha resistido a los fracasos intentó de nuevo pero con productos de mayor rotación  y mas rentables como hasta ahora lo hace y con mayor cuidado con las ventas a crédito.
Con su credikiva comprará cervezas, gaseosas, huevos, galletas, y una licuadora para empezar a vender jugos de frutas y bolis. (Congelados a base de frutas naturales) Este es su primer financiamiento y espera crecer y organizar de nuevo su tienda teniendo el cuidado que se requiere y con mucha disciplina, para cumplir el sueño de mejorar la educación de sus hijos y verlos como unos profesionales en el futuro.
texts.en:
Rosario León A., 38, lives with her partner and two children aged 10 and 14 in the town of Malambo, 15 minutes from the city of Barranquilla. 

She has been selling food and drinks since she arrived from the Antioquia region, where she used to work in a restaurant on a farm, selling lunch to employees. She longed to be independent and, when for the first time there were public safety issues in the area where she lived, she didn't hesitate. She moved with her family to the town where she now lives and set up her own business aged 24, when she was already married.

There were some challenges at first adapting to the new situation, but gradually she and her husband have been "matching their workload". 
Her first capital was the compensation received by her husband when he was working. She used it to set up a store, but poor credit issuing eventually caused bankrupcy. She has always fought failure so she tried again with more profitable products with a high turnover, as well as a more careful approach to issuing credit, which is what she's doing now. 

With the Kiva loan she is going to buy beer, sodas, eggs, biscuits and a blender to start selling fruit juices and "bolis" (frozen fruit juice). This is her first loan and she hopes to grow and reorganise her store with a lot of care and discipline. Her dream is to improve her childrens' education and in future see them become professional people.

loans.use: Buy beer, sodas, eggs, biscuits and a blender to start selling fruit juices and "bolis" (frozen fruit juice).

loans.name: Norma Carlota

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar en el hermoso balneario  de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa, lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

Aquí conocimos a la señora  Norma, tiene 64 años de edad, casada y tuvo 6 hijos ya todos mayores de edad, ella es nacida en Montecristi pero debido a la salud de su esposo tuvieron que irse a vivir a San Jacinto ya hace algunos años. 

Se dedica junto a su esposo a la perfección y venta de sombreros de paja toquilla, trabajan todos los días ya que el proceso del sombrero es un poco complicado, el cual lo realizan con mucho amor porque les gusta lo que ellos hacen,  saben que su trabajo es muy apreciado en muchos lugares hasta donde ellos envían sus productos y además porque les deja buenas ganancias. Los sombreros en forma cruda o semi elaborado los compran en Montecristi, los terminan y los venden a turistas que llegan hasta el local, también entregan a comerciantes que los envían a otros lugares.

Este crédito es para comprar más sombreros. Este es su segundo crédito y le gustan las reuniones.
 
Su sueño es tener una buena salud ella y su esposo.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days the Communal Bank “Esperanza Para Superar” (Hope to Overcome) meets in the beautiful resort town of San Jacinto, which is surrounded by a beautiful beach and where the Portoviejo River meets the sea. This place is visited by many domestic and foreign tourists.

Norma is 64 years old, married, and has six children, all of whom are adults. She was born in Montecristi but had to move because of her husband’s health. They went to San Jacinto where they have lived for the past few years.

Norma and her husband manufacture and sell straw hats. They work together every day since the process of making the hat is a bit complicated. The work they perform is done with much love because they enjoy what they do. Their work is appreciated in several places where their products are shipped and results in good profits. The hats are acquired in Montecristi in crude form or partially assembled. Norma and her husband finish the hats and sell them to tourists who arrive at her store. She also sells to merchants that come from other places.

This loan will be used to buy more hats. Norma is receiving her second loan and enjoys the meetings. Her dream is to have good health for herself and her husband.

loans.use: Purchase straw hats

loans.name: Cruz Amarilis

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar  en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

La señora Cruz  es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y le gusta porque las personas que están en el son serias en lo que hacen, ella es la secretaria. Tiene 27 años de edad, esta casada y tiene un hijo de 8 años el mismo que está en la escuela, el marido es controlador de la cooperativa de transporte  Carlos Alberto Aray.
 
Es una ama de casa que para ayudarse en sus gastos se dedica a hacer trabajos de arreglo personal, pinta uñas, corta cabello, realiza tinturados, entre otros trabajos de belleza. Trabaja  en su casa y a domicilio. Además elabora forros para electrodomésticos los cuales los realiza bajo pedido. Trabaja todos los días  en sus actividades desde las 8h30 hasta las 14h00.

Este crédito es para comprar materiales tanto para elaborar los forros como también esmaltes y otros materiales de belleza. 

Sus sueños son tener un salón de belleza y una microempresa textil.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days the Communal Bank “Esperanza Para Superar” (Hope to Overcome) meets in the beautiful resort town of San Jacinto, which is surrounded by a beautiful beach and where the Portoviejo River meets the sea. This place is visited by many domestic and foreign tourists.

Sra. Cruz is a founding member of her Communal Bank and likes the fact that the people who have joined are serious about what they do. She serves as the group secretary. Cruz is 27 years old, married, and has an eight year old child in school. Her husband works as a dispatcher for the Carlos Alberto Aray transportation cooperative.

Cruz is a homemaker who helps with the expenses by providing personal makeovers, painting nails, cutting and coloring hair, and performing other beauty services in her home. She also makes covers for household appliances upon request. Cruz works every day in all of her activities between the hours of 8:30am and 2pm.

This loan will be used to buy materials for making appliance covers as well as nail polishes and other beauty supplies. Her dreams include opening a beauty salon and a small textile business.

loans.use: Purchase nail polishes, beauty supplies, and materials for making appliance covers

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
One of the most industrious members of ASHI Antique Central Branch is Merlyn B., She is a resident of Oloc, Laua-an, Antique Philippines. She is married to Anastacio B. also an industrious farmer and responsible father to their 3 children. According to Anastacio, “if you are industrious, nothing is impossible for you to reach your dreams” because industry for her is the best weapon against poverty. 

Merlyn joined ASHI because of her dreams and when we talk about dreams, HD Throreau points out that “dreams are the touchstones of our character” just simply because people tend to become industrious, inspired and stronger because of the dreams that they want to reach.

In 2009, when she joined ASHI, Anastacio brought her dreams as a basic requirement for membership. The days after the trainings, she received her first loan amounting  to PHP5, 000.00, which she used as capital for her fish vending business. For her next loan, she has applied for PHP8000.00. This amount will be used as additional capital for fish vending so that they can purchase a volume of fish to sell.

She hopes that, through her business, they will get more income in order to sustain the needs of the family and enable them to send their children to school until college.

loans.use: Fish Vending

loans.name: Jenny Alexandra

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Jenny tiene 47 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha tenido dos hijos de 23 y 12 años de edad, la mayor ya es graduada de la universidad y el menor esta en colegio. Su marido es comerciante.

Ella y su marido tienen un negocio de compra y venta de pescado y camarón, trabajan todos los días, en la madrugada el se desplaza hasta Puerto López donde le compra a los barcos que llegan hasta la playa  ya que allí le salen más baratos ya que son entregados directamente de los pescadores, luego venden en el mercado de Puerto López y el resto lo llevan a San Jacinto donde ella se encarga de vender.
 
Este crédito lo va a emplear para comprar mas de sus productos, es socia del Banco Comunal hace 4 ciclos y está muy conforme porque los créditos le ayudan mucho en su negocio.
 
Su sueño es tener un gran restaurante.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days the Communal Bank “Esperanza Para Superar” (Hope to Overcome) meets in the beautiful resort town of San Jacinto, which is surrounded by a beautiful beach and where the Portoviejo River meets the sea. This place is visited by many domestic and foreign tourists.

Sra. Jenny is 47 years old, in a common law marriage, and has two children (ages 23 and 12). Her older child has already graduated from university while the younger child is in high school. Her husband is a merchant.

Jenny and her husband have a business buying and selling fish and shrimp. They work every day. At dawn her husband goes to Puerto López where he buys from the fishing boats that arrive at the beach. The seafood is cheaper because he buy directly from the fishermen. He later sells at the market in Puerto López and brings what remains to San Jacinto for Jenny to sell.

This loan will be used to buy more products. Jenny has been a member of the Communal Bank for four loan cycles and is very happy because the loans have been a great help to her business. Her dream is to have a large restaurant.

loans.use: Purchase fish & shrimp

loans.name: Tulipanes De Orizaba Group

texts.es:
Esta foto fue tomada en la casa D. Roberta Consuelo H. un integrante del grupo Tulipanes D. Orizaba que está ubicado en el Estado D. Veracruz en México. Se ve al grupo D. mujeres en el bazar D. la señora Roberta que se ubica dentro D. su domicilio en la foto. Ella se dedica a  compra y venta D. muebles y artículos usados que inicio hace 2 años. Solicita el préstamo para compras más muebles y enseres para vender. Sus  clientes la consideran una persona honesta y trabajadora. Al momento D. solicitar este préstamo se siente contenta por reactivar su negocio con más mercancía D. la que tiene actualmente. Tiene 50 años, estudio hasta la carrera D. enfermería, es soltera y tiene en total 1 hijo varón. Quiere este crédito para comprar más cosas usadas para vender y hacer crecer su negocio. También espera poder comprar un terreno para pasar su bazar para allá y adecuar su casa ahí mismo ya que actualmente renta el lugar donD. vive y tiene su bazar.
Margarita J. es la presidente del grupo. Tiene 61 años,  estudió hasta carrera comercial, es casada  y no tiene hijos. Ella se dedica a la venta D. ropa que inicio hace 5 años. Solicita el préstamo para comprar ropa D. temporada para vender.El grupo esta conformado por 9 integrantes.
texts.en:
This picture was taken in the home of Roberta Consuelo H., a group member of Tulipanes from Orizaba which is located in the state of Veracruz in Mexico.   The women in the picture are seen in the variety store located insiD. Roberta's home.  She started buying and selling used furniture and other used items 2 years ago.  She will use the loan to purchase more furniture and appliances to sell.  Her clients consider her to be an honest and hard-working person.  She is very happy upon requesting the loan, knowing she can stock her business with more merchandise than what she has now.  She is 50 years old, single, has one boy, and studied nursing in school.  She wants this loan to purchase more used items to sell and be able to grow her business.  She also hopes to purchase some land so she can move her variety store and build a home there since she currently rents where she is at now.

Margarita J. is the president of the group, she is 61 years old, married, no children, and studied business in school.  Five years ago she began selling clothes and is requesting the loan to purchase clothes that are in season for re-sale.  The group is maD. up of 9 members.

loans.use: Purchase furniture and appliances for re-sale.

loans.name: Las Palmas Ms Group

texts.es:
El grupo Las Palmas MS se encuentra ubicado en L. ciudad D. Monte Salas, Fortín en el Estado D. Veracruz en México y está conformado por 9 integrantes. 

María Susana G. es L. presidente del grupo. Tiene 47 años, estudió hasta 5to. Año D. primaria, es casada y tiene en total 2  hijos. ElL. se dedica a L. venta D. hoja D. platano que inicio hace 20 años. Solicita el préstamo para comprar más hoja D. plátano para asar y vender, porque las personas que hacen tamales le compran las hojas D. platano para hacer los tamales oaxaqueños, que se venden en varios estados D. México. L. señora María Susana necesita incrementar su ventas para mantener económicamente a sus hijos, dado que su esposo está enfermo y no pueD. trabajar. El sueño D. L. señora Susana y D. su esposo es que sus hijos terminen sus estudios. 

L. foto fue tomada en L. casa D. Rosalba L. otra integrante del grupo, se ve a las integrantes del grupo afuera D. L. casa D. doña Rosalba. ElL. se dedica a  venta D. cosméticos desD. hace 19 años. Solicita el préstamo para surtir su mercancía. Tiene 39 años, estudió hasta L. primaria, es soltera y tiene una hija.Sus vecinas D. L. comunidad L. conocen como una persona responsable y trabajadora.ElL. quisiera incrementar sus ventas en esta temporada para lograr poner su local.
texts.en:
The Las Palmas MS group is located in the city of Monte Salas, Fortin in the state of Veracruz, Mexico. The group is maD. up of 9 members.

Maria Susana G is the group president. She is 47 years old, married and has 2 children. She only studied through the 5th graD. of elementary school. For the last 20 years she has been selling banana leaves. She is taking out this loan so that she can buy more banana leaves to cook and sell. People that buy the banana leaves use them to make Oaxacan tomales that are sold in many states in Mexico. Maria Susana needs to increase her sales to continue to proviD. for her children. Her husband is currently sick and cannot work. Susana and her husband's dream is that their children finish their studies. 

This picture was taken in Rosalba's house. The members of the group are seen outsiD. of Rosalba's house. Rosalba has been selling cosmetics for the last 19 years. She is taking out this loan so that she can diversify her product line. She studied through the end of elementary school, she is single and has one daughter. Her neighbors know her as someone that is responsible and a hard worker. She wants to increase her sales this season.

loans.use: Buy banana leaves and sell them

loans.name: María Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

Para la señora María  este es su cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le ha gustado porque a diferencia de otros lugares de crédito aquí no piden tantos requisitos para otorgarlos. Tiene 57 años de edad, está separada hace varios años pero de esta relación tuvo 8 hijos ya todos mayores de edad, dos de ellos viven con ella y uno de ellos  es especial.

Tiene un lugar frente al mar en plena playa de San Jacinto, donde vende ropa de todo tipo, pero lo que más vende es ropa fresca que es utilizada por los turistas que visitan el lugar. Trabaja de viernes a domingo desde las 8 am hasta las 18h00 ya que en estos días llegan muchos turistas. Su mercadería la compra en Guayaquil.

Este crédito es para comprar más mercadería.
  
Su sueño es tener un local en su casa donde pueda vender su mercadería ya que en la playa es muy caluroso.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days the Communal Bank “Esperanza Para Superar” (Hope to Overcome) meets in the beautiful resort town of San Jacinto, which is surrounded by a beautiful beach and where the Portoviejo River meets the sea. This place is visited by many domestic and foreign tourists.

Sra. María is in her fourth loan cycle with the Communal Bank and enjoys being a member because other places that offer credit have more requirements for receiving loans. She is 57 years old and has been separated for many years. Her marriage resulted in eight children, all of whom are adults. Two of them live with her and one has special needs.

María has a beachfront location in San Jacinto where she sells all types of clothing, but the products she sells the most are cool garments worn by tourists that visit the area. She works Friday through Sunday from 8am to 6pm since there are many tourists on those days. María buys her merchandise in Guayaquil.

This loan will be used to buy more merchandise. Her dream is to have a store in her house where she can sell her merchandise because the beach can be very hot.

loans.use: Purchase beach clothing

loans.name: Isabel Martha

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para Superar en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.
 
Aquí encontramos a la señora Isabel, ella tiene 66 años de edad, está casada y tiene 7 hijos  los mismos que ya son mayores de edad, uno de ellos vive en su casa aun. Su marido está muy anciano y ya no trabaja.

Ella tiene un restaurante en su casa, el mismo que está ubicado frente al malecón de San Jacinto, trabaja todos los días desde las 8 am hasta las 18h00 y en tiempo de temporada playera hasta las 22h00,  prepara una gran variedad de platos y su especialidad son los camarones y el pescado  apanados con ensalada y patacones. Ya tiene 20 años en su negocio y dice que hay temporadas bajas pero que en la temporada playera todo se recupera.

Este crédito es para comprar productos que sirvan para la preparación de los alimentos. Lleva en el Banco Comunal ya tres años y siempre le ha gustado por las reuniones ya que en ellas se divierte con sus amigas.
 
Su deseo es seguir trabajando y tener buena salud.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days the Communal Bank “Esperanza Para Superar” (Hope to Overcome) meets in the beautiful resort town of San Jacinto, which is surrounded by a beautiful beach and where the Portoviejo River meets the sea. This place is visited by many domestic and foreign tourists.

Sra. Isabel is 66 years old, married, and has seven adult children, one of whom still lives at home with her. Her husband is elderly and no longer works.

Isabel has a restaurant in her home located on the waterfront in San Jacinto. She works every day from 8am to 6pm, and during the beach season she works until 10pm. Isabel prepares a wide variety of dishes and her specialties are breaded shrimp and fish with salad and plantains. She has been in business for 20 years and says that there are slow moments, but is able to recover everything during the beach season.

This loan will be used to buy products for serving the food she prepares. Isabel joined the Communal Bank three years ago and has always enjoyed the meetings because she has fun with her friends. Her wish is to continue working and enjoy good health.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Pastora Genedi

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.
 
La señora Pastora es socia del Banco Comunal desde hace dos años y le gusta el banco por la seriedad de las compañeras,  esta muy agradecida con la Fundación Espoir por la ayuda que le han brindado para salir adelante. Tiene 48 años de edad y está casada  hace 30 años, de esta linda unión tuvo cuatro hijos los cuales son mayores de edad e independientes, solo una hija vive con ella con sus dos hijos pequeños. Su marido es comerciante.

Se dedica a la compra y venta de pescado junto a su esposo, el se levanta muy de mañana y se va a la playa donde llegan los pescadores en sus pangas y canoas trayendo el fruto de su trabajo y allí ellos le entregan su mercancía, el mismo que luego  lleva hasta su casa para que la señora Pastora le ayude a limpiar para luego revenderlo a comerciantes que llevan el pescado a Quito.

Este crédito es para comprar pescado ya que el dinero esta invertido y necesitan de capital para poder surtirse y no dejar a sus clientes inconformes.
 
Su sueño es tener una casa más amplia y mejor arreglada.
texts.en:
The 'Esperanza Para Superar' community bank meets every two weeks in the beautiful seaside resort of San Jacinto, surrounded by a beautiful beach where the Portoviejo river meets the sea.  This place is visited by many national and international tourists.

Pastora has been a member of the community bank for two years and she likes the bank because of the reliability of her companions.  She is very grateful to Fundación Espoir for the support which they have given her to help her get ahead.  Pastora is 48 years old and has been married for 30 years.  From this beautiful marriage she has four children who are all grown up and independent.  Only one daughter lives with her, together with her two small children.  Her husband is a merchant.

Pastora buys and sells fish together with her husband.  He gets up very early every morning and goes to the beach where the fishermen arrive in their skiffs and canoes, bringing with them the fruit of their labor.  They hand over their goods which Pastora's husband then takes home so that Pastora can help him to clean them and then resell them to traders who take the fish to Quito.

This loan will be used to buy fish since their money is invested and they need capital to be able to stock up and not leave her customers dissatisfied.

Her dream is to be have a bigger, better house.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Zoa Filomena

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es  visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.

La señora Zoa tiene 39 años de edad y es madre soltera de dos hijos de 13 y 10 años, el mayor esta en colegio y la menor en escuela, esta viviendo en la casa de la mamá a la espera de que el gobierno le construya su casita ya que salió favorecida para recibir su casa. Nos cuenta la socia que la vida ha sido muy dura con dos hijos pequeños que alimentar y educar.

Es así como con mucho esfuerzo puso un pequeño restaurant donde vende una buena variedad de platos, en las mañanas vende encebolladlos y en las tardes y noches tiene menú y platos a la carta, lleva ya tres años con su negocio y le ha ido bien a pesar de todo. Trabaja todos los días desde las 5am hasta la noche.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar  productos para la preparación de los alimentos. Está en el Banco Comunal hace tres ciclos y esta muy contenta porque los créditos le han sacado de muchos apuros.

Sus sueños son tener su casa y algún día un local propio ya que en el que esta es arrendado.
texts.en:
The Esperanza Para Superar community bank meets every two weeks in the beautiful seaside resort of San Jacinto, surrounded by a beautiful beach where the Portoviejo river meets the sea.  This place is visited by many national and international tourists.

Zoa is 39 years old.  She is a single mother and has two children aged 13 and 10.  The eldest is in high school and the youngest is in elementary school.  Zoa lives in her mother's home and is waiting for the government to build her a small house because she was approved to receive one.  She tells us that life has been very hard with two small children to feed and educate.

With a lot of hard work, Zoa set up a small restaurant where she sells a good variety of dishes.  In the mornings she sells 'encebollados' (fish and onion stew) and in the afternoons and evenings she offers a fixed menu and à la carte dishes.  She has been in her business for three years and it has done very well in spite of everything.  She works every day from 5.00am until night.

This loan will be used to purchase products for food preparation.  She has been in the community bank for three loan cycles and is very happy because the loans have got her out of many difficult situations.

Her dreams are to have her own home and, some day, her own premises since her current premises are rented.

loans.use: To buy food supplies

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza  O. is 37-years old, married, and supports her family by operating a pig fattening business. She lives in Sitio Pasil, Barangay Punao, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts by working hard in her pig fattening business. She is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000.00.

Analiza  is now borrowing PHP 14000 so that she can purchase more pigs. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Analiza  aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase new assets.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chet

texts.en: Chet S., 42, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. S. sells rice, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of about USD 2 per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more rice to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more rice to resell.

loans.name: Chel

texts.en: Chel N., 45, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. N. sells sugar cane, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of about USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend USD 45 on food, USD 10 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  N. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more sugar cane to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits she can earn to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy more sugar cane to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan R. is from the village of Mapulog, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old, married, and has 3 grown children. To make a living, Susan owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing karaoke services to local community members, for which customers pay 5 pesos per song. She is also operating a sari-sari (variety) store, at which she sells beverages and all kinds of junk food and snacks as an additional way of generating income. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her services. This will be Susan’s 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide her services

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more materials to use for decorating fabric

loans.name: Heoung

texts.en: Heoung P., 45, is widowed and resides with her 4 children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. P. is a farmer and raises animals, earning an income of USD 1.5 per day. Three of her children are employed at the factories, where each earns an income of about USD 2 and helps cover the family expenses. The family has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 3 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.  P. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase more pig food to feed pigs. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits she earns to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy pig food to feed pigs

loans.name: Arv

texts.en: Arv K., 54, is widowed and resides with her three children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. K. produces roofs traditionally made from palm leaves, earning an income of USD 2 per day. The family has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 8 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more roofs to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more palm leaf roofs to resell

loans.name: Mun

texts.en: Mun N., 39, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. N. decorates fabrics at home, earning an income of about USD 2.50 per day. Her husband is a fisherman, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. The family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 10 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  N. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more supplements to decorate fabrics. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more supplements to decorate fabrics to sell

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely S. is from the village of Maputi, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old. Fely is married and has three school-aged children. To make a andliving, Fely owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing repair services of computers, television set, and also DVD components and players. She is also continuing the buying and selling a variety of fish and other sea products in the market. Fely has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Fely is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Fely from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Se

texts.en: Se K., 59, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. K. grows bananas to sell, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband refills lighters’ gas, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. The family has to spend USD 40 on food, USD 8 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase fertilizer to grow bananas and gas to refill the lighters. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. K.'s husband appears in the photograph because K. is not available.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to grow bananas

loans.name: Marlene Margarita

texts.es:
Cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Esperanza Para  Superar en el hermoso balneario de San Jacinto, rodeado de una playa hermosa lugar donde el Rio Portoviejo se une con el mar. Este lugar es visitado por muchos turistas nacionales y extranjeros.
 
En este hermoso  lugar encontramos a la señora Marlene, tiene 39 años de edad, está casada y tiene 3 hijos de 19 – 17 y 9 años, estudian uno en la universidad, otro en el colegio y el ultimo en la escuela. El esposo es comerciante de mariscos.

Es artesana y elabora infinidad de diseños y tejidos, realiza tejidos de nido de abeja en almohadas y edredones los mismos que son muy apreciados por los turistas que llegan hasta ese lugar, la pagan muy bien ya que son un bonito detalle para llevar de recuerdo, también hace trabajos bajo pedido y los vende a  comerciantes que llevan a otros lugares, trabaja de lunes a viernes desde las 8h30 hasta las 16h00 y en algunos días hasta más tarde cuando tiene muchos pedidos.

Este crédito es para comprar materiales para la elaboración de sus productos. Tiene 4 ciclos en el Banco Comunal y está muy contenta por las facilidades de pago.
 
Su sueño  es tener un gran taller para elaborar mayor cantidad y poder mostrar su arte en otros países.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days, the Esperanza Para Esperar [Hope to Overcome Communal Bank] meets in the beautiful San Jacinto coastal resort town, surrounded by a beautiful beach. At this place the Portoviejo River meets the sea. Many tourists, both national and foreign, visit this place.

In this beautiful place we find Marlene. She is 39 years old, married, and has 3 children aged 19, 17, and 9. One is studying in university, anoother in high school, and the youngest in primary school. Her husband sells shellfish. She is an artisan of cloths and makes countless designs and woven items.

She crochets designs of honeybee nests into pillows and quilts, which are highly valued by tourists who arrive there. They pay her very well, as they are pretty things to take home as souvenirs. She also makes goods of lesser demand, which she sells to vendors who take the goods to other places. She works Monday through Friday from 8:30am until 4:00pm, and sometimes later on days when there is high demand. 

This loan is to buy materials for the creation of her products. She has had 4 loan cycles in the Communal Bank and is very happy for the ease with which she has paid them back. 

Her dream is to have a big workshop to make a greater quantity of products and to be able to show her art in other countries.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, quilts, etc.

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en: Sourn Khem, 60, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kandal Province, Cambodia, an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. Khem decorates fabrics and grows fruit trees at home, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 8 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month. Khem is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland and more supplements to decorate fabrics. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland and more supplements to decorate fabrics

loans.name: Beberly

texts.en:
Beberly A. is from the village of Mapulog, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Beberly owns & operates a livestock business, raising pigs and chickens for sale. Beberly has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Beberly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Beberly is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Choy

texts.en:
Choy M., 31, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kandal Province, Cambodia: an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. M. decorates fabrics at home, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a mechanic, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 40 on food, USD 10 on electricity and water supplies and USD 15 on other necessary expenses every month.  

M. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more materials to decorate fabrics. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy more materials to decorate fabrics

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda G. is 46 years old, married and supports her family by operating 1 business venture: an electronics repair/spare-parts  business. She lives in Zone 1, Brgy. Tagda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,000. 

Linda is now borrowing PHP 19,000 so that she can continue to fund operation of her electronics repair shop. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Linda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to fund operation of her electronics repair business

loans.name: Liv

texts.en:
Liv Y., 54, is widowed and resides with her husband and two children in Kandal Province, Cambodia: an area known for fertile farmland for growing vegetables. Y. sells fish, earning an income of about USD 3.5 per day. The family has to spend USD 45 on food, USD 10 on electricity and water supplies and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. 

Y. appears in the photograph at home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Elie

texts.en:
Elie C. is from the village of Mapulog, Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old, widowed and has 3 school-aged children. Elie owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells a variety of ocean caught fish like bangus and bilong-bilong. She also harvests and sells coconuts for extra income. Elie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela O. is a married woman who lives in Zone 5, Brgy. Tagda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She operates 2 business ventures: fishing and fish vending. Her husband Roquelo O., who is 52 years old, works as a fisherman and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children aged between 19 and 29. 

Carmela joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 7 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Carmela has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her to earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, lifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 8th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000. She intends to use this as addtional capital for her business so that she can continue to save up for the future and for her daily needs. Carmela O. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

Currently, one of her sons wants to work in Thailand as a garment worker, but Sok Y. doesn’t have enough money to pay his document fee.  

Sok Y. is requesting a loan to pay the document fee for her son to go to overseas. She proposes to use the remainder of the loan to purchase more silk skirts to sell in order to earn extra profit.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn  N. is a married woman who lives in Purok Punta Tundo, Brgy. Pilar, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  Fishing and Pig Fattening businesses. Her husband Reymondo N., who is 47 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 2 and  13 years old. 

Jocelyn  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jocelyn  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use to buy fishing gear  so that she can continue to save up for the future and for the education of her children.

 Jocelyn  N. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

They have been married since 1990 and have three children--two sons and one daughter. loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Chhuon C. is a 45-year-old farmer who lives in province of Kompong Chhnang. Chhuon C. is married to Mr. Vanna, age 43, who works with her in the farming business. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland that they inherited from their grandparents. From this business they can generate an income of around US$ 4 per day. This humble couple has two single children who are students. This rainy season, the family planted more vegetables and some fruit on their own farmland two months ago but their crops are not growing well due to the lack of fertilizer. Because of this condition, Chhuon C. needs a loan from Kiva in order to buy fertilizers to improve her vegetable and fruit yield.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to improve her vegetable and fruit yield

texts.en:
Carmelina G. is 60 years old and married. She supports her family by operating two business ventures:  Fishing and Farming businesses. She lives in Luyong Baybay, Brgy. Tacup, San Remegio, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts, by working hard in her  fishing and farming businesses. Carmelina is now borrowing PHP 14,500 so that she can purchase fishing gear and other equipment. This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Carmelina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary T. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Vibol Chan, have been married since 1999 and have two sons. Both of them are in school. They live in a small village along National Road Number 5 about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mrs. Mary T. has been a tailor for more than three years. Her husband has been driving a motor Remorque for more than one year. (A Remorque is a motorbike attached to a trailer at the back). Besides the businesses, the couple grows rice as well. 

Mary has requested a Kiva loan twice already. She is now is asking for her third loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm. She also will use a part of her loan to buy a new motorbike because the old one breaks down and does not work well.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm and replace her old motorbike.
