loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros S., 48, grows vegetables, and catches and sells fish at the local market of his Kandal province. He typically makes US$3 of profit each day, while his wife stays at home looking after their four children. Two of the children are in school and the two others are employed as garment factory workers. Ros S. is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase one boat and grow sugar cane.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and plant sugar cane.

loans.name: Asterie

texts.en: Asterie is 33 years old. She is single. She sells mineral water and yellow bananas, and has spent 9 months in this business. With this loan she will buy more mineral water and yellow bananas to sell. With the profit from this business she will purchase more cartons of mineral water. She says that her business is successful because it is commonly known by her customers. In the future, she would like to become a wholesale supplier to other sellers.

loans.use: To buy more mineral water and yellow bananas to sell.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng B., 25, is married and lives with her two young children in Kandal province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works in construction making US$5 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Seng B. included. Seng B. is asking for a loan of US$600 to finish her construction.

loans.use: To finish her construction.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent is 31 years old. He is single. Innocent sells a variety of items such as utensils and glasses in his shop, and has spent 2 years in this business. With this loan he will buy more utensils to sell. With the profit from the business he will increase the volume of his business. His business is successful because he provides good customer service. In the future, he would like to be a wholesale supplier for other dealers of utensils and glasses.

loans.use: To buy more utensils to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary L. lives in the Kyebando Nsooba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 5 children, two of whom are in school. Mary has a business of poultry farming. She has been in this business for 3 years and she works 7 days out of every week. Mary sells her products from home, by means of wholesale.

Mary has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more chicken feed. She also generates additional income through farming. The main business challenge(s) for Mary include transportation of chicken feed and poultry diseases. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own 1000 chickens and also to own a delivery van for transporting chicken feed. Mary lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feed.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy essential materials.

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie P. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 37 years old. Josie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Josie owns and operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motorcycle transport in the local community. Josie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair the existing vehicle for better service. Josie is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and needed materials to provide services. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and needed materials to provide services.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea S. is 52 years old and lives with her husband and three of her children in Kandal province. To earn a living, she has been making and selling cakes in the local market and is able to make about US$6 every day. Her husband is a farmer, typically making US$1 a day. This couple also gets support from two children who are garment factory workers. Chea S. is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Eron

texts.en:
Eron N. lives in the Kyebando Nsooba neighborhood in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, three of whom are in school. Eron lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food for the family.

Eron is in the business of selling clothes. She has been doing so for over ten years and works seven days out of every week. Eron sells her clothing at the market for retail prices. She also generates additional income through farming.

Eron has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. The main business challenges for Eron include transportation and the rainy season that hinders her customers from reaching her. Her goal for her business is to start importing secondhand clothes.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S. is 47 years old and lives in Kandal province in Cambodia. She is a farmer who works for 2 USD in profits every day.

The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Sok S. included. She is asking for a loan of 600 USD to purchase more farmland.

loans.use: To purchase more farmland

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette is 32 years old and single. She sells various items such as beauty soaps, lotions and tomato sauce in her shop. She has been in this business for nine years. She says that her business is successful because her shop is very popular.

With this loan Jeannette will buy more lotions and tomato sauce to sell. With the profits she will purchase new items for sale. In the future she would prefer to have a big shop as a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy more lotions and tomato sauce to sell

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina F. is from the village of Brgy. Darubba, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Adelina owns a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Adelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. This will be the second loan taken out by Adelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of her immediate family. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product line

loans.name: Boak

texts.en: Boak P., 38, sells grocery items in the local market in Kandal province. She is married with two children, who are still living at home, and her husband is a farmer. She typically makes about US$6 each day, and would like a loan to expand her business in order to increase her profits. She is asking for US$400 to increase her grocery stock.

loans.use: To increase her grocery stock.

loans.name: Mui

texts.en:
Mui T. N. is 44 years-old and she has three children.  They are in high school and university.  

She is a farmer . Her main activities are growing rice and raising pigs for meat.  Doing this work for many years, she has created a stable income for managing her family life and paying big school fees.  Joining with our credit program in 2006, she is always in a good repayment situation. Currently, she is in need of a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy fertilizer and feed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and feed.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen S. is 21 years old and lives with her husband in Kandal province. She is a farmer and also sells pork making a daily profit of US$4. Her husband is a photographer. On average, he earns US$5 per day. The couple has one young child. Yen S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a hand tractor to plow her farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor.

loans.name: Ma. Suzette

texts.en:
Ma. Suzette A. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 43 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Suzette owns a business raising pigs to fatten and sell. Ma. Suzette has been engaged in her business for over two years and makes approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her grown pigs.

In 2009, Ma. Suzette joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Ma. Suzette from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma N. lives in the Kawala neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is in school. Fatuma has had a canteen business for 10 years, and  works six days a week. She sells her products at the near-by school. Fatuma has requested a loan of  400,000/= Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, to buy more cakes, donuts, biscuits, samosas and bread for her canteen. She also generates additional income through renting rooms. Her main business challenges include school holidays and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build more rental rooms and to get permanent business premises. Fatuma lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bread, donuts, samosas, and cakes for her canteen

loans.name: Arsenio

texts.en:
Arsenio F. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 48 years old. Arsenio is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Arsenio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Arsenio has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Arsenio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arsenio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Arsenio is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Arsenio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Tam

texts.en: Tam T.  N. is 36 years old with two children who are attending  high school.  Being a farmer, she has been  growing rice and corn  and raising pigs for many years. Her agricultural products are used as food to support her family. A part of  her agricultural yield is sold to earn daily income.  Receiving our loans since 2006, she has used them effectively in expanding her farming. Currently, she wants to have  a loan of 4,142,000 VND to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Saom L. is 28 years old and sells used phones at the local market of Kandal province. She typically makes US$ 10 per day. Her husband, pictured here, works transfering data and songs into mobile phone. On average, he makes US$ 5 a day. Saom L. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase more used phones to sell.

loans.use: Sell used phones

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita D. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 46 years old. Anita is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Anita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Anita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tu

texts.en: Tu T. N. is 47 years old. She is a farmer with one child. She has been running a farm for many years. She grows rice, beans and vegetables, and is raising 200 chickens. She sells eggs wholesale and retail to earn daily income. Tu T. N. has been participating with SEDA's credit program since 2006, and she has used loans effectively in expanding her farm. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 7,194,000 dong (VND) to buy food for chickens.

loans.use: To buy food for chickens

loans.name: Giramahoro Group

texts.fr:
Emmanuel N. est un commerçant âgé de 28 ans qui habite au Quartier Kamenge en Mairie de Bujumbura. Il fait le commerce des articles de boutique, un métier qu’il exerce depuis 5ans alors qu’il était cultivateur. Il a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e année de l’école primaire. Il est marié à Rukundo Marie, elle-même commerçante. Ils ont 2 enfants âgés de 3ans et de 2ans. Il arrive au 3e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Il demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  en achetant de grandes quantités de  produits de boutique à revendre aux clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Il a préféré demander le crédit à Turame car le capital qu’il avait auparavant était très insuffisant pour faire ce business. Il a l’espoir de combattre la pauvreté et pouvoir assurer la scolarité de ses enfants avec le crédit de Turame.

Il  est un des membres du groupe  communautaire« Giramahoro I».
texts.en:
Emmanuel N. is a 28-year-old shopkeeper who lives in the Kamenge district of Bujumbura. He used to be farmer, but has sold grocery items for the last 5 years. He completed the 6th year of primary school. He is married to Rukundo Marie, who is also in the business. They have two children aged 3 and 2.
Emmanuel is on his 3rd group loan cycle with Turame. He is requesting a Kiva loan to increase his capital buy purchasing large quantities of goods to sell to his customers, and thereby increase his savings. The capital he had before was insufficient for this business. He hopes to overcome poverty and to guarantee his children’s education with this loan through Turame.
Emmanuel is a member of the Giramahoro I Community Group.

loans.use: Increase capital by purchasing large quantities of retail items

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet K. lives in  Wandegeya Katanga neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  Juliet has a tailoring business.  She has been in this business for five years, and she works six days out of every week. Juliet sells her products from home, retail.    

Juliet has requested a loan of 300,000/= Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of cloth and thread. She also generates additional income through selling second-hand clothes.The main business challenges for Juliet include defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching out to her.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build her own house and also to buy a cloth designing machine and an overlock sewing machine.    

Juliet lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of clothing materials and thread

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ilkin

texts.ru:
Ilkin S. 26 let. On jenat i imeyet dochku kotoroy 2 qoda. Ilkin yavlyayetsya IDP pesonom , on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas projivayets v Fuzuli regione, posolok Bala Behmenli vmeste so svoyey semyoy.

Ilkin uje 4 qoda kak v etom biznese skotovodstva. Seychas Ilkin nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korov dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Ilkin S. is 26 years old.  He is married and has a 2-year-old daughter.  Ilkin is an IDP.  He is a refugee from the Fuzuli region and now lives in the Bala Behmenli village in the Fuzuli region with his family.

Ilkin has been involved in the animal husbandry business for 4 years.  He currently needs 2000 AZN in order to buy cattle and develop his business.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites B. is 40 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Santa Rosa in the municipality of Gamu, Isabela province on the islands of Luzon. Marites raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her pigs.

In 2008, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. Marites is requesting a new loan, her fifth from ASKI, of 12,000 PHP that will be used to purchase more piglets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets

loans.name: Mai

texts.en: Mai T. V. is 48 years old with two children who are attending college. She is a farmer who cultivates 2,160 square meters. Mai grows rice, fresh vegetables, and corn. She has been a client of SEDA since 2006 and has effectively used loans in the past. Mai is requesting a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy fertilizer and a tow truck to reduce her labor force.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and a tow truck

loans.name: Minh

texts.en: Minh T. G. is a 53-year-old farmer with two children who are workers. Her main activities are raising eight pigs and growing rice and beans. Since receiving her first loan in 2006, Minh has invested in expanding her farm. She has been successfully and productively raising pigs that bring good prices. Minh is requesting a loan of 8,066,000 VND to improve her pigsties.

loans.use: to improve pigsties

loans.name: Cherrymel

texts.en:
Cherrymel T. is 24 years old, married and has an infant. She is from the village of Villa Verde in the barangay of Balulang within Cagayan de Oro City, Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Cherrymel runs a retail store from which she primarily buys and sells electronic reloads of several networks like GLOBE, SMART and SUN CELLULAR to the local community. Cherrymel has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Cherrymel joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Cherrymel successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to purchase additional electronic reloads to sell. Cherrymel is requesting a new loan, her second from HSPFI, of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa M. is 26 years old and has a husband who is a business man. She has two children, one of whom goes to school.

Hawa is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to work on building a house.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Svay R., 45 years old, owns a small shop located in front of her house where she sells coffee. She typically makes around US$ 3 in profit each day to support her family. Svay R. has been married for many years to Mr. Nou Kan, 59, a local farmer, and they now have two school-aged children, one of whom attends university while the other one attends a high school.

Svay R., is running her business smoothly because she has skills in public relations which she uses with her customers. Currently, she wants to earn more extra income by feeding a few pigs around her house, but she doesn’t have cash to make that possible. Therefore, Svay R. is requesting a loan to purchase pigs to fatten to add more profit.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to fatten

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden F. is from the village of La Paz, Saguday, Quirino. She is 35 years old. Eden is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Eden owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Eden has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Eden joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eden has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Eden is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Eden from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anh

texts.en: Anh T. H. M. is a 33-year-old farmer with two children who attend secondary school. She grows rice, beans, and eggplant and raises pigs as her main agricultural activities. Anh produces a stable food source and considerable daily income for her family. She joined the SEDA credit program in 2006 and has a good credit history. Anh is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND to invest in her business.

loans.use: to invest in her business

loans.name: Perfecta

texts.en:
Perfecta E. is a married woman who lives in Camp Valdez, Brgy. Mambaroto, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  Tobacco vending and vegetable vending businesses. Her husband Mamerto E., who is 56 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have ten children between 15 and  36 years old. 

Perfecta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Perfecta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for tobacco vending so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Perfecta E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of tobacco sales

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

texts.en: Asunta K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and groundnuts and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Asunta is 46 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has three children and two of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Huyen

texts.en: Huyen T. T. N. is 29 years old and has 1 small child. She is a farmer who is raising 200 chickens for eggs. She has run this kind of business for many years and makes a good income from it. Since becoming a client of our credit program in 2006, she has used loans effectively in expanding her business. Currently, she wants a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy food for chickens.

loans.use: to buy food for chickens.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice T.  is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Joice is 34 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Phuong T. T. is 24 years old and has 2 children who are at primary school. She has been running a shop that sells jeans in the central market for many years. Her business expanded more when she accessed loans from SEDA in 2006. Her shop generates 4,500,000 profit per month. Currently, she wants a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy more new season jeans to meet the demands of the teenage market.

loans.use: to buy more jeans for resale

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita B. is 48 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. She is from the village of Namnama in the barangay of Magsaysay, a part of the municipality of Saguday, Quirino province on the islands of Luzon. Lolita operates a tailoring business from which she provides general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 29 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2006 Lolita joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Lolita successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional fabric and materials. Lolita is requesting a new loan, her eighth from ASKI, of 20,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional fabric and materials. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabric and materials

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle L. is 39 years old, married and supports her family by operating two businesses: fishing and fish vending. She lives in Purok 1 in the barangay of Culipapa, Hinobaan municipality in Negros Occidental province on the Mindanao islands. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6000.

Anabelle is now borrowing PHP 17,000, her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, to purchase fishing gear and equipment. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Anabelle aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure its future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ernest

texts.en: Ernest, age 52, is a married man with 11 children living in a permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He deals in farming and goat raring. He wants his children to study up to university so that they can have a good future. He dreams of being a lifetime animal farmer. He wants a loan to pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for the children.

loans.name: Chean

texts.en:
Chean R. has been in the farming business for many years. She plants various crops to earn a living and normally generates an income of 2.5 USD per day. Her husband frequently works in the farm fields alongside her.

Most of her family’s income comes from her child who sells groceries next to her village. She hopes to encourage her child’s business by expanding the amount of necessary groceries to sell, but she has no cash to make that possible. To solve the problem, Chean R. is requesting a loan to purchase more groceries for her daughter to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her daughter to sell

loans.name: Anh

texts.en: Anh T. N. is 31 years old and has 2 children who are at primary school. He has been a truck driver for 5 years. Everyday, he goes to the soil beach to deliver soil to construction sites. He generates a good revenue from this business. Since becoming a client of SEDA in 2009, he has been a good repayer. Currently, he wants a loan of 7,194,000 VND to maintain his vehicle.

loans.use: to maintain his vehicle

loans.name: Bong

texts.en: Bong T. N. is 55 years old and has one child. She is a farmer who grows corn, rice and vegetables in paddies of 1,500 square meters. As she has  a lot of experience in farming, she can meet the full food demand of her  family and generate a stable daily income. Since joining our credit program in 2007, she has always been in a good repayment situation. Now she wants a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy fertilizer and seed  for the next crop.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seed for the next crop.

loans.name: Reynelda

texts.en:
Reynelda A. is forty years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Tinabalan outside Gingoog City in Misamis Oriental province on the islands of Mindanao. Reynelda runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells canned goods and snacks to the local community. She also buys and sells electronic reloads from several networks like GLOBE and SMART. Reynelda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Reynelda joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 3000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Johnny

texts.en:
Johnny O., from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya, is 37 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Johnny has been raising pigs for breeding for over six years, earning approximately 3500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Johnny joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid his previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase breeding livestock, he is now requesting his third loan for 14000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Johnny plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Maqbool's Group

texts.en:
Maqbool lives in Kasur, which is a small city of Pakistan and famous for its leather industry. She lives with her family in a 2 room brick house. 
She is an embroidery expert. She not only sews clothes, but also does very creative embroidery on them. Due to her work and good service to her customers, she receives regular orders. Her husband, M. L., is involved in selling bed sheets. Maqbool is the mother of 3 sons and 2 daughters. She couldn’t provide education facilities to her elder children, but they now do embroidery to contribute to their family financially. Due to their financial support, Maqbool has now enrolled her two younger children to school.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy bed sheets in bulk quantity and increase his sales. Maqbool has a great confidence in her husband and his abilities. She is sure that by using his 10 years of working experience in this field, he will be able to successfully upgrade his business with this investment.

loans.use: To buy bed sheets in bulk quantity for resale.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en: Josephat, age 35, wants a loan to purchase beans, maize and groundnuts for reselling. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He owns a semi-permanent house in which he lives with his wife and seven children. He earns income from buying and selling beans, maize and groundnuts, which he dreams of making a permanent business.

loans.use: To purchase beans, maize and groundnuts for reselling.

loans.name: Remelita

texts.en:
Remelita M. is from the village of Anakan, Gingoog City. She is 55 years old. Remelita is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Remelita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, instant noodles, junk food, and detergents in the local community. Remelita has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Remelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Remelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Remelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Blenda

texts.en:
Blenda A. is from the village of Sta. Rosa. She is 41 years old. Blenda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Blenda owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Blenda has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Blenda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Blenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Blenda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Blenda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Phoung

texts.en: Phoung L., 28, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband is a construction foreman. On average, he makes US$3.50 of profit a day. This couple has two children, who still live at home. Phoung L. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase a hand tractor.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem C., 27, is a professional scarf weaver. She weaves and sells scarves in her local market in Takeo province. She is married with two children, who still live at home, and her husband sells banana ice cream. She typically makes about US$2.50 each day, and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$1000 to raise pigs and cows.

loans.use: To raise pigs.

loans.name: Rizan

texts.en:
Rizan M. is from the village of Santiago, Gingoog City. He is 22 years old. Rizan is widowed and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Rizan owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorela or multi-purpose tricycle services to local community members. Rizan has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rizan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rizan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed for the maintenance of the motorela. Rizan is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools and other materials needed for the maintenance of the motorela. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rizan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. K., 60 years old, is a good mother blessed with six children. Half of her children are married and the remaining two are single. They all work at different occupations, and have a proper income every month. Mrs. K. was married and her husband died of senility many years ago. Mrs. K. operates her own small handicraft business, mainly weaving rattan baskets and cupboards. She has a son who assists her with weaving and selling rattan.

Recently, she has been concerned that her son is married, and wants to build a new house to live independently, but unfortunately, Mrs. K.’s savings account is not enough to support her son. So, Mrs. K. would like to request a loan to buy a wooden house for her son to live in.

loans.use: To buy a wooden house for her son to live in.

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: Moeun N., 32, is a professional tailor, making US$3 each day in Takeo province. She is married and has two children living at home to support. Her husband makes approximately US$5 every day, recharging batteries. Moeun N. would like a loan of US$1200 to raise cows.

loans.use: To raise cows.

loans.name: Ngen

texts.en: Ngen V., 35, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband is a cow dealer. On average, he makes US$3.50 of profit a day. This couple has three children, who still live at home. Ngen V. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase cows.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Tamemsu Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Tamemsu” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Masorie village, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking for a loan of SLL 700,000 for each. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and, consequently, improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Jatu S.. Jatu is age 30. She was born in Nahothi village. She is married to a farmer and the couple has four children who are attending both primary and secondary schools, respectively. 

Jatu is a businesswoman and a farmer. She has been doing business for 15 years now. She wants this loan in order to invest in her business. She will buy rice, groundnuts, palm oil and “bennine” in larger quantities to sell.

loans.use: To buy rice, groundnuts, palm oil and “bennine” in larger quantities to sell

loans.name: Geraldina

texts.en:
Geraldina B. is from the village of Santiago, Gingoog City. She is 37 years old. Geraldina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Geraldina owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling snacks and other delicacies like rice cakes and cassava cakes in the local community. Geraldina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Geraldina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Geraldina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Geraldina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients and working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Geraldina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao L. is 50 years old and sells fruits in Battambang province. Her business has been around for about five years and she makes US$15 every day. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike to transport fruit.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Tawop Asorbeh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Tawop Asorbeh” group from Masorie, a village in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to seek a loan of SLL 700,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and, consequently, improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ramatu K.. Ramatu was born in Masorie village about 37 years ago. She is married to a businessman and has five children who are attending school. Ramatu has been a businesswoman for 10 years now. She sells rice. With her share of this loan, she will buy bags of rice to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice to add to her business

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Ouk D., 35, sells beverages in a local school in Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with one child, who still lives at home, and her husband is a car driver. She typically makes about US$20 in revenue each day, and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$1000 to purchase more beverages.

loans.use: To purchase more beverages.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline is 42 years old. She is married and has 7 children between the ages of 1 and 22. Six children are enrolled in school. Jacqueline sells meat with her husband, and has had this business for the 10 years. With this loan she will buy more kilograms of meat to sell. With the profit from this business she will increase the quantity of meat she has been selling. Her business is well-known and that is why she is successful. In the future, she would like to prosper to the extent of supplying to other butchers.

loans.use: To buy more kilograms of meat to sell.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 38 years old. She is married and has 7 children between the ages of 1 and 15. Six of her children are enrolled in school. Her husband works as a driver. Francoise sells food stuffs such as maize flour and rice, and has spent 10 years in this business.

With this loan, she will buy more sacks of maize flour and rice to sell. With the profit from this business she will increase the volume of sales. She says her business succeeds because her shop is very popular. In the future, she would like to have a standard business to the extent of becoming the supplier to others.

loans.use: To buy more maize flour and rice to sell.

loans.name: Khadra

texts.en: Khadra is 46 year old woman, married, with one child. Khadra is interested in renting wedding dresses, and she works at her home. The financiA. state of this family is terrible, so she’s obliged to help her husband in raising their child. She needs a small loan from A. Majmoua to enhance her job. Her essentiA. purpose is the continuity in her work as a woman. Her dream is to create more and more ideas to develop her business. Her clients are her relatives and friends, but in the future she would like to attract a big number of clients from all over the country.

loans.use: To enhance her job.

loans.name: Be Honest Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Be Honest” group. They are small-scale businesspeople, farmers and a building contractor. They are residents of the village of Masorie in northern Sierra Leone. They are asking for a loan of SLL 700,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses or invest in their farms. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is John P. K.. John is age 39 and was born in Massorie village.  He is married and has six children. Three  of the children are in primary school and three are in secondary school.  

John P. K. is a professional building contractor and has been in this profession for eight years now. However, John is going to invest this loan in farming and in business. In business, he will buy rice and palm oil to sell.

loans.use: To buy rice and palm oil to sell

loans.name: Phy

texts.en: Phy C., 30, sells grocery items in her village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with two children, who still live at home, and her husband works collecting palm juice and operating a grind mill. She typically makes about US$6 each day, and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$800 to increase the stock of her groceries and to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Oum

texts.en:
Oum C. is a 48 year old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province. Oum C. was married, but her husband died several years ago. She has a life partner in her daughter, who sells grocery items in her community in order to earn additional profit. Oum C. normally works in the field with her daughter. Oum C. currently generates an income of approximately $2.50 per day from her farmland.

Oum C.’s daughter wants to expand her stock for more sales, but she doesn’t have the funds yet. So, Oum C. will use her loan for her daughter to purchase additional grocery products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Yost

texts.en: Yost Y. is 60 years old and lives with his wife and five of his children in Kampong Chhnang province. He is a chief villager, and he is also has a grinding mill business. He typically makes US$4 of profit a day. His wife sells gasoline from home and earns US$3 per day as well. Three of the children are in school, while two are technicians. Yost Y. is asking for a loan of US$200 to buy more gasoline for his wife to sell and also to fix his leaking roof.

loans.use: To sell gasoline.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 42 years old. She is married and has 5 children between the ages of 16 and 28. Two of her children are enrolled in school and three of them have completed their university. Her husband does not work. Marie sells milk, and with this loan she will buy more liters of milk to sell. With the profit from the business she will pay school fees for her children. She says that her business is successful because the community likes milk.

In the future, she would like to be a distributor of milk in the whole district.

loans.use: To buy more liters of milk to sell.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent is 27 years old. He is single. He has adopted 3 children. Innocent sells beer and soft drinks, and he has had this business for 6 years. With this loan he will buy more beer and soft drinks to sell. With the profit he will buy food for his family. His business is unique because he is the only person who sells beer and soft drinks. In the future, he would like to become the sole distributor in the whole sector.

loans.use: To buy more beer and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: We Believe We Self Group

texts.en:
Memunatu K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Memunatu was born in Makeni city about 32 years ago. She is married to a teacher and the couple has three children who are attending school. For seven years now, Memunatu has been selling gara lappers (locally dyed cloths) and slippers. 

This is not the first loan that Memunatu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. However, with the help of this new loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Memunatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business. She will buy gara lappers making materials like caustic soda, powder, inks, white cotton cloths, etc. in order to produce a larger quantity of gara cloths. She will also buy dozen of slippers to add to her business. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower, Rugiatu K., who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy gara lapper making materials (caustic soda, powder, inks, white cotton cloths, etc) and slippers to add to her business

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng N., 40, is married with six children living at home in the Kampong Chhnang province. She grows rice and raises pigs, typically making US$2 each day. Her husband sells coconuts, and typically makes US$3 each day. Cheng N. would like a loan of US$500 to finish her construction.

loans.use: To finish construction.

loans.name: Tas-Wop N' Sorbeh Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Isatu K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born 45 years ago in one of the villages that makes up Sanda, Isatu is married and has four children.  For many years now, Isatu has been selling palm oil (the favorite cooking oil), vegetable oil, fish, etc.  Isatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business. She will buy palm oil, vegetable oil and fish in large quantity. 

This is not the first loan that Isatu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this new loan however, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower, Fatu K., who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy palm oil, vegetable oil and fish in large quantity

loans.name: Abasse

texts.en: Abasse is a 31-year-old father with two children. He sells clothes in Tyre. Since he can’t rely on this job the entire year, Abasse would like to start a new job selling phone lines for additional income. He needs a small loan from AlMajmoua. He taken a previous loan from AlMajmoua and has a good reputation.

loans.use: To start a new job selling phone lines

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is 27 years old. She is married with two children between the ages of one and four. One of her children goes to school. Her husband works as a house builder. Christine sells food utensils and children's clothing. She has had this business for ten years. With this loan she will buy more food utensils to sell. With the profit she will save money. Her business is successful because of her connection to her customers. In the future she would like to have a big sum of money so that she can buy more stock to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food utensils to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more containers of frozen meat

loans.name: Verene

texts.en: Verene is 30 years old. She is married and has two children between the ages of five and seven. Both of her children are enrolled in school. Her husband works as a businessman. Verena sells furniture. She has had this business for seven years. With this loan she will buy new equipment for the business. With the profit from the business she will renovate her house. She says that her business is successful because people buy furniture from her. In the future she would like to prosper by importing salon equipment and sell them to salon users.

loans.use: To buy new equipment for her business.

loans.name: Ramatulai

texts.en: This is 36 year-old Ramatulai. She is single with one 16-year-old child. She has one additional dependent, who lives with her because she needs a helper.  In 2006, Ramatulai established her shoes, slippers, textiles, clothing and soft drinks business. She began her business to support herself and her child after she dropped out of school. Her business has proven profitable over the years. Working six days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about 2,438,960SLL every month from this business. She needs a loan of 3,000,000SLL. Ramatulai requires a loan in order to rent a shop and buy more stock for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 609,740SLL. Ramatulai intends to use the proceeds from this loan to send her daughter to the university. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To rent a shop, and buy some shoes, clothing and drinks for her business

loans.name: Without Money Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Without Money” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This is not the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With the help of previous loans, they were able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Memuna C.. Memuna is age 55. She was born in Freetown but currently resides in Makeni together with her husband and four children. Her husband is a farmer. One of her children is attending primary school and three are in secondary school. For 10 years now, Memuna has been selling dishes, rubber bowls, palm oil, etc. With this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items in large number to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy dishes, rubber bowls, palm oil, etc.

loans.name: Barham

texts.fr: Monsieur Barham D. est un jeune homme de 24 ans qui habite dans la communauté rurale de Bambilor. Il est célibataire sans enfant. Monsieur D. s’active depuis plus d’un an  dans l’achat et la vente de produits agricoles tels que les semences, les insecticides, etc. Il a acquit l’expérience de son grand frère qui fait la même  activité. Par la suite il a ouvert une succursale pour pouvoir voler de ses propres ailes. Et a travers son activité il parvient à satisfaire ses propres  besoins. Il est membre de la caisse de Bambilor depuis juin 2010 et n’a jamais bénéficié de crédit  au sein de la dite institution. Il sollicite un prêt de 200 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de produits (insecticides, engrais, semences) qui vont servir à renforcer son stock. L’accroissement de ses bénéfices lui permettra de mieux se prendre en charge et surtout de renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
Mr. Barham D. is a young, 24-year-old man who lives in the rural community of Bambilor. He is single and doesn’t have any children. 

For over a year, Mr. D. has been involved in buying and selling agricultural products such as seeds, insecticides, etc. He benefited from the experience of his older brother, who is in the same business. He eventually opened a shop to make it on his own. This activity allows him to earn a living. 

He has been a member of the Bambilor credit union since June 2010 but had not received any credit until now. He is requesting a loan of 200,000 francs to increase his stocks by purchasing merchandise (insecticides, fertilizers, seeds). The boost in his profits will enable him to better support himself, and especially to bolster his savings.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, sugar and flour.

loans.name: Alex  F.

texts.en: This is 27-year-old Alex. He is married, and has two children aged one and three years old. In 2004, Alex established his business selling mobile phones, DVD Laptops and accessories. He began his business when he dropped out of school. He has been successful in business. Working six days a week and nine hours a day, he earns about 2,640,000SLL every month from this business. He needs a loan of 3,000,000SLL. Alex requires a loan in order to buy more electrical goods. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profit by approximately 528,000SLL. In the future, Alex plans to open an electronics shop and send his first child to a private school. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phones, laptops and accessories

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a 36-year-old single mother with four children. She runs a retail shop and lives in a permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. She dreams of constructing a personal permanent house for her family and transforming her retail shop into a wholesale shop. She wants a loan to purchase beer and soda to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase beer and soda to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Serapio

texts.en: Serapio, aged 40 years, is a married man with eight children. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He started by selling crop yields from which he got capital to start up a retail shop. He dreams of educating his children and keeping his family in good health. He also wants to become a wholesaler so he'll have a big size business. He wants a loan to buy more bags of rice to resell.

loans.use: To purchase rice to resell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes wants a loan to purchase women, men and children's wear to sell in her clothing shop. She is a 28-year-old lady married with four children who lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. Agnes operates a clothing shop where she sells clothing for men, women and children. She dreams of educating her children and turning her shop into a big boutique.

loans.use: To purchase women's, men's and children's wear to sell in her clothing shop.

loans.name: Sidratu  D

texts.en: This is 46-year-old Sidratu. She is married and has three children who are 22, 17, and 15 years old. She has one additional dependent, a relative who lives with her. In 2007, Sidratu established her beverage business, selling soft drinks, rum, gin and water. She began her business because she realized that her salary was not enough to provide for her children. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, she earns about 1,285,000 SLL every month from this business. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL in order to buy more drinks for resale. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 205,600 SLL. In the future, Sidratu plans to expand her business to a bar and restaurant. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for resale

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline A. is a married lady with four children between the ages of two and six. Her husband is self employed. They hope to provide a good education for their children, educating them to the university level. Caroline is served by the Kitengela branch of SMEP. Her business, Mama Davy's shop, is located at Mukuru kwa Njenga and is well known. At Mama Davy's shop, Caroline provides tailoring services by making suits, skirts, and trousers for local people. Also in her shop, she stocks rice, bread, sugar, detergents, and other general items, which she sells to her repeat customers. She says that this business is profitable and she only has one major challenge: customers have a variety of choices because there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 50,000 KES to buy more fabric to expand her business and meet her customers' demand. In the future, she hopes to open her own boutique. She describes herself as hardworking and humble.

loans.use: To purchase fabric

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria M. is 51 years old, single, and the mother of three grown children. Her business is located in a residential area in Nairobi. For the past year, she has been selling clothes to passers-by and regular customers. She says that this business is profitable and that her major challenge is a lack of finances. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more clothes, which include skirts and trousers, in order to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to grow her business to a boutique. She describes herself as a hardworking and happy lady.

loans.use: To purchase clothes

loans.name: Inkingi Group

texts.fr:
Claudine U. est une  commerçante âgée de 23 ans qui habite au Quartier Kamenge en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de produits vivriers au Marché de Kamenge, un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 10ans. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 7e année de l’école secondaire. Elle est célibataire. Elle arrivait au 10e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame mais elle intègre maintenant le crédit solidaire. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  en achetant de grandes quantités de produits vivriers à revendre aux clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Elle a préféré demander le crédit à Turame car elle a beaucoup de facilités à rembourser. Elle compte diversifier les produits à vendre dans l’avenir si son capital parvient à augmenter. Le crédit de Turame lui a faciliter a assurer les besoins de sa famille y compris la scolarisation de ses cadets du fait qu’elle est la responsable dans la famille.
 
Elle  est une des membres du groupe  solidaire« Inkingi».
texts.en: Claudine U. is a 23 year-old shopkeeper who lives in the Kamenge neighborhood of Mairie de Bujumbura. She sells food products at the Kamenge market, a line of work she has been in for 10 years. She attended school until the seventh grade of middle school. She is single. She is on her tenth cycle of group loans with Turame, but now also incorporates an individual loan.  She is requesting a Kiva loan to increase her capital by purchasing large quantities of food products to resell to customers and thus be able to increase her savings. She preferred to request the Turama loan because it will be easy for her to repay.  She plans to diversify the products she sells in the future if she manages to raise the capital.  The Turama loan will help her provide for her family, including the education of her younger siblings, because she is in charge of her family.  She is a member of the « Inkingi» solidarity group.

loans.use: To increase her capital by purchasing large quantities of food products to resell to customers and thus be able to increase her savings.

loans.name: Akuwa

texts.fr: Akuwa est une femme  de 35 ans, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de tôles qui sert à couvrir le toit des maisons au  Togo. La plupart de sa clientèle est composée d’entrepreneurs. La demande de sa clientèle est toujours élevée, en ce moment son stock  ne lui permet pas de servir  toute sa clientèle. Elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit  pour s’approvisionner avec 4 douzaines de tôles. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle a déjà obtenu de WAGES 2 crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.
texts.en: Akuwa is a 35 year old woman whose line of business is the retail sale of sheet metal used to cover the roofs of houses in Togo. Most of her customers are entrepreneurs. Her customer demand is always high, but currently she does not have enough stock  to serve all her customers. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to stock up with 4 dozen sheets. She is married and the mother of two children. She has already obtained two  loans from WAGES that she has fully repaid.

loans.use: Purchase of sheet metal

loans.name: Umugisha Group

texts.fr:
Emmanuel H. est un commerçant âgé de 53 ans qui habite au Quartier Cibitoke en Mairie de Bujumbura. Il achète des tissus et les fait confectionner lui-même en divers types d’habits et les vend au Marché Central  de Bujumbura, un métier qu’il exerce depuis 25ans. Il a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 2e année de l’école primaire. Il arrive au 7e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 
Il est père de 7 enfants.

Il demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  en achetant de grandes quantités de  tissus pour habits à revendre aux clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Il a préféré demander le crédit à Turame car les bénéfices générés de ce crédit lui aide à assurer les besoins familiaux y compris les frais de scolarité de ses enfants. 

Il  est un des membres du groupe  communautaire« Umugisha».
texts.en:
Emmanuel H. is a 53-year old entrepreneur who lives in the Cibitoke   neighborhood of Mairie de Bujumbura. He purchases fabrics to make different types of outfits from and sells the outfits the Centeral Market of Bujumbura. He has been in this business for 25 years. He has finished middle school. He is now on his seventh group loan with Turam.

 He is the father of seven children. He is seeking a loan from Kiva to boost his capital in order to purchase more cloth for outfits to be sold and thus to grow his savings. He prefers to take out a loan from Turame since the income made possible through this income allows him to provide for his family, including the payment of his children’s school fees. He belongs to the “Umugisha” community group.

loans.use: Increasing his capital by purchasing a large volume for fabrics to make clothing for sale

loans.name: Dossou

texts.fr: Dossou est un homme très dynamique, il exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de peintures, il fait ce commerce dans sa propre boutique qu’il a appelé « ETS LA GLOIRE ».  Il s’approvisionne à Lomé. Le crédit qu’il sollicite va lui permettre d’accroître son stock de marchandise avec  10 boîtes de peintures AG, 15 boîtes de peintures LEYLAC, 12 boîtes de verni, 9 boîtes de peintures BASS, 10 boîtes de diluant.
texts.en: Dossou is a very energetic man. He makes a living by selling paint. He has his own stores which he had named “Glory, Inc.” He stocks up in Lomé. The loan he is seeking will allow him to increase his merchandise stock by 10 cans of AG paint, 15 cans of Leylac paint, 12 cans of varnish, 9 cans of Bass paint, 10 cans of diluent.

loans.use: Purchasing paint

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose M. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Rose is 33 years old and is married to a soldier. She has three children and only one of them goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes M. is thirty-two years old. She is single and has three children between the ages of twelve and three. Her business is located at a very busy market in Mwingi and is known Mama ka Kim. Agnes is served by the Thika branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. 

Agnes provides tailoring services by making clothes such as skirts, blouses, dresses and shirts. She serves the local people, and she has been in this business for five years now. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that her customers take too long in coming to pick up the clothes, therefore delaying payments and tying up her capital. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more materials to expand her business and meet the customers' needs. In the future, she hopes to open a wholesale shop for selling materials. She also sees herself giving her children a good education up to the university level. She describes herself as hardworking, ambitious and quiet.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Kokui

texts.fr: Kokoui est une femme au foyer avec 3 enfants.
